item.title: Atropo‐Enantioselective Oxidation‐Enabled Iridium(III)‐Catalyzed C−H Arylations with Aryl Boronic Esters
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, Volume 60, Issue 34, Page 18532-18536, August 16, 2021.
item.dc:description:
A highly atropo‐enantioselective C−H arylation of tetralone derivatives paired with aryl boronic esters as nucleophilic components is presented. The transformation is catalyzed by chiral cyclopentadienyl (Cpx) iridium(III) complexes and enabled by oxidatively enhanced reductive elimination from high‐valent cyclometalated Ir‐species.
Abstract Atropo‐enantioselective biaryl coupling through C−H bond functionalization is an emerging technology allowing direct construction of axially chiral molecules. This approach is largely limited to electrophilic coupling partners. We report a highly atropo‐enantioselective C−H arylation of tetralone derivatives paired with aryl boronic esters as nucleophilic components. The transformation is catalyzed by chiral cyclopentadienyl (Cpx) iridium(III) complexes and enabled by oxidatively enhanced reductive elimination from high‐valent cyclometalated Ir‐species.
item.content:encoded:
A highly atropo-enantioselective C−H arylation of tetralone derivatives paired with aryl boronic esters as nucleophilic components is presented. The transformation is catalyzed by chiral cyclopentadienyl (Cpx) iridium(III) complexes and enabled by oxidatively enhanced reductive elimination from high-valent cyclometalated Ir-species.


Abstract

Atropo-enantioselective biaryl coupling through C−H bond functionalization is an emerging technology allowing direct construction of axially chiral molecules. This approach is largely limited to electrophilic coupling partners. We report a highly atropo-enantioselective C−H arylation of tetralone derivatives paired with aryl boronic esters as nucleophilic components. The transformation is catalyzed by chiral cyclopentadienyl (Cpx) iridium(III) complexes and enabled by oxidatively enhanced reductive elimination from high-valent cyclometalated Ir-species.
item.dc:creator: Łukasz Woźniak, Nicolai Cramer
item.dc:title: Atropo‐Enantioselective Oxidation‐Enabled Iridium(III)‐Catalyzed C−H Arylations with Aryl Boronic Esters

item.title: Nickel‐Catalyzed, Reductive C(sp3)−Si Cross‐Coupling of α‐Cyano Alkyl Electrophiles and Chlorosilanes
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, Volume 60, Issue 34, Page 18587-18590, August 16, 2021.
item.dc:description:
An activated alkyl electrophile and a silicon electrophile can be reductively cross‐coupled under nickel catalysis with elemental zinc as the stoichiometric reductant. This cross‐electrophile coupling enables for the first time the formation of a C(sp3)−Si bond from alkyl electrophiles with an α‐cyano group and chlorosilanes (see Scheme; dtbpy=4,4′‐di‐tert‐butyl‐2,2′‐dipyridyl).
Abstract A nickel/zinc‐catalyzed cross‐electrophile coupling of alkyl electrophiles activated by an α‐cyano group and chlorosilanes is reported. Elemental zinc is the stoichiometric reductant in this reductive coupling process. By this, a C(sp3)−Si bond can be formed starting from two electrophilic reactants whereas previous methods rely on the combination of carbon nucleophiles and silicon electrophiles or vice versa.
item.content:encoded:
An activated alkyl electrophile and a silicon electrophile can be reductively cross-coupled under nickel catalysis with elemental zinc as the stoichiometric reductant. This cross-electrophile coupling enables for the first time the formation of a C(sp3)−Si bond from alkyl electrophiles with an α-cyano group and chlorosilanes (see Scheme; dtbpy=4,4′-di-tert-butyl-2,2′-dipyridyl).


Abstract

A nickel/zinc-catalyzed cross-electrophile coupling of alkyl electrophiles activated by an α-cyano group and chlorosilanes is reported. Elemental zinc is the stoichiometric reductant in this reductive coupling process. By this, a C(sp3)−Si bond can be formed starting from two electrophilic reactants whereas previous methods rely on the combination of carbon nucleophiles and silicon electrophiles or vice versa.
item.dc:creator: Liangliang Zhang, Martin Oestreich
item.dc:title: Nickel‐Catalyzed, Reductive C(sp3)−Si Cross‐Coupling of α‐Cyano Alkyl Electrophiles and Chlorosilanes

item.title: Double Ionic–Electronic Transfer Interface Layers for All‐Solid‐State Lithium Batteries
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, Volume 60, Issue 34, Page 18448-18453, August 16, 2021.
item.dc:description:
The double ionic–electronic transfer interface layers between electrode and electrolyte were created by in situ polymerization of 2,2′‐bithiophene inside the solid‐state lithium battery, resulting in low interface resistance and highly stable interface contact.
Abstract Large‐scale implementation of all‐solid‐state lithium batteries is impeded by the physical limitations of the interface between the electrode and solid electrolyte; specifically, high resistance and poor stability, as well as poor compatibility with Li+ migration. We report double ionic–electronic transfer interface layers grown at electrode–electrolyte interfaces by in situ polymerization of 2,2′‐bithiophene in polyethylene oxide (PEO) electrolyte. For all‐solid‐state LiFePO4∥PT‐PEO‐PT∥Li cells, the formation of a conductive polythiophene (PT) layer at the cathode–electrolyte interface resulted in an at least sevenfold decrease in interface resistance, and realized a capacity retention of about 94 % after 1000 cycles along with a lower polarization voltage under a rate of 2 C. The mixed ionic–electronic conductive layers imparted superior interface stability and contact while keeping good compatibility with the Li anode.
item.content:encoded:
The double ionic–electronic transfer interface layers between electrode and electrolyte were created by in situ polymerization of 2,2′-bithiophene inside the solid-state lithium battery, resulting in low interface resistance and highly stable interface contact.


Abstract

Large-scale implementation of all-solid-state lithium batteries is impeded by the physical limitations of the interface between the electrode and solid electrolyte; specifically, high resistance and poor stability, as well as poor compatibility with Li+ migration. We report double ionic–electronic transfer interface layers grown at electrode–electrolyte interfaces by in situ polymerization of 2,2′-bithiophene in polyethylene oxide (PEO) electrolyte. For all-solid-state LiFePO4∥PT-PEO-PT∥Li cells, the formation of a conductive polythiophene (PT) layer at the cathode–electrolyte interface resulted in an at least sevenfold decrease in interface resistance, and realized a capacity retention of about 94 % after 1000 cycles along with a lower polarization voltage under a rate of 2 C. The mixed ionic–electronic conductive layers imparted superior interface stability and contact while keeping good compatibility with the Li anode.
item.dc:creator: Jingang Zheng, Chengguo Sun, Zhenxing Wang, Shaojun Liu, Baigang An, Zhenhua Sun, Feng Li
item.dc:title: Double Ionic–Electronic Transfer Interface Layers for All‐Solid‐State Lithium Batteries

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Generation of Diazomethyl Radicals by Hydrogen Atom Abstraction and Their Cycloaddition with Alkenes
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, Volume 60, Issue 34, Page 18484-18488, August 16, 2021.
item.dc:description:
A new approach for the generation of diazomethyl radicals and their addition to alkenes is described. The direct hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) from α‐diazo compounds generates electrophilic diazomethyl radicals, thereby reversing the reactivity of the diazo carbon. This umpolung strategy overcomes the limitations of electron‐deficient alkenes in traditional dipolar [3+2]‐cycloaddition of α‐diazo compounds with alkenes.
Abstract A general catalytic methodology for the synthesis of pyrazolines from α‐diazo compounds and conjugated alkenes is reported. The direct hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) process of α‐diazo compounds promoted by the tert‐butylperoxy radical generates electrophilic diazomethyl radicals, thereby reversing the reactivity of the carbon atom attached with the diazo group. The regiocontrolled addition of diazomethyl radicals to carbon‐carbon double bonds followed by intramolecular ring closure on the terminal diazo nitrogen and tautomerization affords a diverse set of pyrazolines in good yields with excellent regioselectivity. This strategy overcomes the limitations of electron‐deficient alkenes in traditional dipolar [3+2]‐cycloaddition of α‐diazo compounds with alkenes. Furthermore, the straightforward formation of the diazomethyl radicals provides umpolung reactivity, thus opening new opportunities for the versatile transformations of diazo compounds.
item.content:encoded:
A new approach for the generation of diazomethyl radicals and their addition to alkenes is described. The direct hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) from α-diazo compounds generates electrophilic diazomethyl radicals, thereby reversing the reactivity of the diazo carbon. This umpolung strategy overcomes the limitations of electron-deficient alkenes in traditional dipolar [3+2]-cycloaddition of α-diazo compounds with alkenes.


Abstract

A general catalytic methodology for the synthesis of pyrazolines from α-diazo compounds and conjugated alkenes is reported. The direct hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) process of α-diazo compounds promoted by the tert-butylperoxy radical generates electrophilic diazomethyl radicals, thereby reversing the reactivity of the carbon atom attached with the diazo group. The regiocontrolled addition of diazomethyl radicals to carbon-carbon double bonds followed by intramolecular ring closure on the terminal diazo nitrogen and tautomerization affords a diverse set of pyrazolines in good yields with excellent regioselectivity. This strategy overcomes the limitations of electron-deficient alkenes in traditional dipolar [3+2]-cycloaddition of α-diazo compounds with alkenes. Furthermore, the straightforward formation of the diazomethyl radicals provides umpolung reactivity, thus opening new opportunities for the versatile transformations of diazo compounds.

item.dc:title: Generation of Diazomethyl Radicals by Hydrogen Atom Abstraction and Their Cycloaddition with Alkenes

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Epitaxial Nickel Ferrocyanide Stabilizes Jahn–Teller Distortions of Manganese Ferrocyanide for Sodium‐Ion Batteries
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, Volume 60, Issue 34, Page 18519-18526, August 16, 2021.
item.dc:description:
A Mn‐based Prussian Blue analogue prone to destabilizing Jahn–Teller distortions upon oxidation is coated with an epitaxial layer of Ni‐based Prussian Blue. This outer layer exerts an anisotropic strain on the lattice of the inner layer, largely preventing structural degradation during Na+ extraction and re‐insertion. As a sodium‐ion battery cathode, the material combines the high capacity and high stability of its two components.
Abstract Manganese‐based Prussian Blue, Na2−δMn[Fe(CN)6] (MnPB), is a good candidate for sodium‐ion battery cathode materials due to its high capacity. However, it suffers from severe capacity decay during battery cycling due to the destabilizing Jahn–Teller distortions it undergoes as Mn2+ is oxidized to Mn3+. Herein, the structure is stabilized by a thin epitaxial surface layer of nickel‐based Prussian Blue (Na2−δNi[Fe(CN)6]). The one‐pot synthesis relies on a chelating agent with an unequal affinity for Mn2+ and Ni2+ ions, which prevents Ni2+ from reacting until the Mn2+ is consumed. This is a new and simpler synthesis of core–shell materials, which usually needs several steps. The material has an electrochemical capacity of 93 mA h g−1, of which it retains 96 % after 500 charge–discharge cycles (vs. 37 % for MnPB). Its rate capability is also remarkable: at 4 A g−1 (ca. 55 C) it can reversibly store 70 mA h g−1, which is also reflected in its diffusion coefficient of ca. 10−8 cm2 s−1. The epitaxial outer layer appears to exert an anisotropic strain on the inner layer, preventing the Jahn–Teller distortions it normally undergoes during de‐sodiation.
item.content:encoded:
A Mn-based Prussian Blue analogue prone to destabilizing Jahn–Teller distortions upon oxidation is coated with an epitaxial layer of Ni-based Prussian Blue. This outer layer exerts an anisotropic strain on the lattice of the inner layer, largely preventing structural degradation during Na+ extraction and re-insertion. As a sodium-ion battery cathode, the material combines the high capacity and high stability of its two components.


Abstract

Manganese-based Prussian Blue, Na2−δMn[Fe(CN)6] (MnPB), is a good candidate for sodium-ion battery cathode materials due to its high capacity. However, it suffers from severe capacity decay during battery cycling due to the destabilizing Jahn–Teller distortions it undergoes as Mn2+ is oxidized to Mn3+. Herein, the structure is stabilized by a thin epitaxial surface layer of nickel-based Prussian Blue (Na2−δNi[Fe(CN)6]). The one-pot synthesis relies on a chelating agent with an unequal affinity for Mn2+ and Ni2+ ions, which prevents Ni2+ from reacting until the Mn2+ is consumed. This is a new and simpler synthesis of core–shell materials, which usually needs several steps. The material has an electrochemical capacity of 93 mA h g−1, of which it retains 96 % after 500 charge–discharge cycles (vs. 37 % for MnPB). Its rate capability is also remarkable: at 4 A g−1 (ca. 55 C) it can reversibly store 70 mA h g−1, which is also reflected in its diffusion coefficient of ca. 10−8 cm2 s−1. The epitaxial outer layer appears to exert an anisotropic strain on the inner layer, preventing the Jahn–Teller distortions it normally undergoes during de-sodiation.

item.dc:title: Epitaxial Nickel Ferrocyanide Stabilizes Jahn–Teller Distortions of Manganese Ferrocyanide for Sodium‐Ion Batteries

item.title: Catalytic Reduction of N2 to Borylamine at a Molybdenum Complex
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Catalytic formation of N−B bonds from atmospheric N2, chloroboranes and electrons is achieved with (triphosphine)molybdenum complexes.
Abstract Catalytic formation of borylamines from atmospheric N2 is achieved for the first time using a series of homogenous (triphosphine)Mo complexes. Stepwise functionalization of the (triphosphine)Mo‐nitrido complex with chloroborane led to the synthesis of the imido complex. Electrochemical characterization of the (PPP)Mo‐nitrido and (PPP)Mo‐borylimido complexes showed that the latter is much more easily reduced.
item.content:encoded:
Catalytic formation of N−B bonds from atmospheric N2, chloroboranes and electrons is achieved with (triphosphine)molybdenum complexes.


Abstract

Catalytic formation of borylamines from atmospheric N2 is achieved for the first time using a series of homogenous (triphosphine)Mo complexes. Stepwise functionalization of the (triphosphine)Mo-nitrido complex with chloroborane led to the synthesis of the imido complex. Electrochemical characterization of the (PPP)Mo-nitrido and (PPP)Mo-borylimido complexes showed that the latter is much more easily reduced.
item.dc:creator: Soukaina Bennaamane, Maria F. Espada, Andrea Mulas, Théo Personeni, Nathalie Saffon‐Merceron, Marie Fustier‐Boutignon, Christophe Bucher, Nicolas Mézailles
item.dc:title: Catalytic Reduction of N2 to Borylamine at a Molybdenum Complex

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Understanding the Roles of Electrogenerated Co3+ and Co4+ in Selectivity‐Tuned 5‐Hydroxymethylfurfural Oxidation
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A detailed mechanism for cobalt‐catalyzed electrochemical 5‐hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation is revealed. A combined experimental and theoretical study shows that a Co3+ species is capable of oxidizing the formyl group to produce carboxylate but remains inert towards oxidation of the hydroxyl group. In contrast, a Co4+ species is required for the initial oxidation of the hydroxyl group in HMF.
Abstract The Co‐based electrocatalyst is among the most promising candidates for electrochemical oxidation of 5‐hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). However, the intrinsic active sites and detailed mechanism of this catalyst remains unclear. We combine experimental evidence and a theoretical study to show that electrogenerated Co3+ and Co4+ species act as chemical oxidants but with distinct roles in selective HMF oxidation. It is found that Co3+ is only capable of oxidizing formyl group to produce carboxylate while Co4+ is required for the initial oxidation of hydroxyl group with significantly faster kinetics. As a result, the product distribution shows explicit dependence on the Co oxidation states and selective production of 5‐hydroxymethyl‐2‐furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) and 2,5‐furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) are achieved by tuning the applied potential. This work offers essential mechanistic insight on Co‐catalyzed organic oxidation reactions and might guide the design of more efficient electrocatalysts.
item.content:encoded:
A detailed mechanism for cobalt-catalyzed electrochemical 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation is revealed. A combined experimental and theoretical study shows that a Co3+ species is capable of oxidizing the formyl group to produce carboxylate but remains inert towards oxidation of the hydroxyl group. In contrast, a Co4+ species is required for the initial oxidation of the hydroxyl group in HMF.


Abstract

The Co-based electrocatalyst is among the most promising candidates for electrochemical oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). However, the intrinsic active sites and detailed mechanism of this catalyst remains unclear. We combine experimental evidence and a theoretical study to show that electrogenerated Co3+ and Co4+ species act as chemical oxidants but with distinct roles in selective HMF oxidation. It is found that Co3+ is only capable of oxidizing formyl group to produce carboxylate while Co4+ is required for the initial oxidation of hydroxyl group with significantly faster kinetics. As a result, the product distribution shows explicit dependence on the Co oxidation states and selective production of 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) are achieved by tuning the applied potential. This work offers essential mechanistic insight on Co-catalyzed organic oxidation reactions and might guide the design of more efficient electrocatalysts.
item.dc:creator: Xiaohui Deng, Ge‐Yang Xu, Yue‐Jiao Zhang, Lei Wang, Jiujun Zhang, Jian‐Feng Li, Xian‐Zhu Fu, Jing‐Li Luo
item.dc:title: Understanding the Roles of Electrogenerated Co3+ and Co4+ in Selectivity‐Tuned 5‐Hydroxymethylfurfural Oxidation

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Mass Spectrometry Imaging Reveals in situ Behaviors of Multiple Components in Aerosol Particles
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: A novel mass spectrometry imaging strategy to trace and quantify carbonaceous particles in situ is reported by Jie Sun, Caiqiao Xiong, Zongxiu Nie et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202103874). The method provides not only spatial biodistribution of carbonaceous aerosol at sub‐organ level, but also chemical information of multiple components from these particles based on their intrinsic fingerprints upon laser ablation. This work provides a new ambition to understand how ambient particles translocate and release its surface organic matter in vivo.
item.content:encoded: A novel mass spectrometry imaging strategy to trace and quantify carbonaceous particles in situ is reported by Jie Sun, Caiqiao Xiong, Zongxiu Nie et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202103874). The method provides not only spatial biodistribution of carbonaceous aerosol at sub-organ level, but also chemical information of multiple components from these particles based on their intrinsic fingerprints upon laser ablation. This work provides a new ambition to understand how ambient particles translocate and release its surface organic matter in vivo.
item.dc:creator: Yuming Jiang, Jie Sun, Caiqiao Xiong, Huihui Liu, Yuze Li, Xiao Wang, Zongxiu Nie
item.dc:title: Mass Spectrometry Imaging Reveals in situ Behaviors of Multiple Components in Aerosol Particles

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Benchmark Acetylene Binding Affinity and Separation through Induced Fit in a Flexible Hybrid Ultramicroporous Material
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
We introduce the new flexible physisorbent sql‐SIFSIX‐bpe‐Zn and reveal that it exhibits an induced fit structural change that results in extraordinary affinity for C2H2 that in turn enables high selectivity for separation of C2H2 over C2H4 and CO2.
Abstract Structural changes at the active site of an enzyme induced by binding to a substrate molecule can result in enhanced activity in biological systems. Herein, we report that the new hybrid ultramicroporous material sql‐SIFSIX‐bpe‐Zn exhibits an induced fit binding mechanism when exposed to acetylene, C2H2. The resulting phase change affords exceptionally strong C2H2 binding that in turn enables highly selective C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/CO2 separation demonstrated by dynamic breakthrough experiments. sql‐SIFSIX‐bpe‐Zn was observed to exhibit at least four phases: as‐synthesised (α); activated (β); and C2H2 induced phases (β′ and γ). sql‐SIFSIX‐bpe‐Zn‐β exhibited strong affinity for C2H2 at ambient conditions as demonstrated by benchmark isosteric heat of adsorption (Qst) of 67.5 kJ mol−1 validated through in situ pressure gradient differential scanning calorimetry (PG‐DSC). Further, in situ characterisation and DFT calculations provide insight into the mechanism of the C2H2 induced fit transformation, binding positions and the nature of host‐guest and guest‐guest interactions.
item.content:encoded:
We introduce the new flexible physisorbent sql-SIFSIX-bpe-Zn and reveal that it exhibits an induced fit structural change that results in extraordinary affinity for C2H2 that in turn enables high selectivity for separation of C2H2 over C2H4 and CO2.


Abstract

Structural changes at the active site of an enzyme induced by binding to a substrate molecule can result in enhanced activity in biological systems. Herein, we report that the new hybrid ultramicroporous material sql-SIFSIX-bpe-Zn exhibits an induced fit binding mechanism when exposed to acetylene, C2H2. The resulting phase change affords exceptionally strong C2H2 binding that in turn enables highly selective C2H2/C2H4 and C2H2/CO2 separation demonstrated by dynamic breakthrough experiments. sql-SIFSIX-bpe-Zn was observed to exhibit at least four phases: as-synthesised (α); activated (β); and C2H2 induced phases (β′ and γ). sql-SIFSIX-bpe-Zn-β exhibited strong affinity for C2H2 at ambient conditions as demonstrated by benchmark isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of 67.5 kJ mol−1 validated through in situ pressure gradient differential scanning calorimetry (PG-DSC). Further, in situ characterisation and DFT calculations provide insight into the mechanism of the C2H2 induced fit transformation, binding positions and the nature of host-guest and guest-guest interactions.

item.dc:title: Benchmark Acetylene Binding Affinity and Separation through Induced Fit in a Flexible Hybrid Ultramicroporous Material

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Fluoride Chemistry in Tin Halide Perovskites
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: The crystallization of tin‐based perovskites is improved thanks to the fluoride in SnF2. The anion of this typical additive is responsible for a more homogeneous nucleation in solution‐processed perovskite thin film formation. In addition, fluoride selectively complexes SnIV and prevents its incorporation in the perovskite structure, as reported by Jorge Pascual, Antonio Abate et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202107599).
item.content:encoded: The crystallization of tin-based perovskites is improved thanks to the fluoride in SnF2. The anion of this typical additive is responsible for a more homogeneous nucleation in solution-processed perovskite thin film formation. In addition, fluoride selectively complexes SnIV and prevents its incorporation in the perovskite structure, as reported by Jorge Pascual, Antonio Abate et al. in their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202107599).

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: HPM‐16, a Stable Interrupted Zeolite with a Multidimensional Mixed Medium–Large Pore System Containing Supercages
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
HPM‐16 is a new interrupted zeolite with 3D intersecting 12+10×10(12)×12+10 MR channels containing 30 Å long supercages. The structure, with a very long b‐axis (>50 Å), was solved by state‐of‐the‐art 3D electron diffraction. Degermanated HPM‐16 is stable up to 800 °C. Several derived structures were studied, including one recently reported.
Abstract HPM‐16 is a highly porous germanosilicate zeolite with an interrupted framework that contains a three‐dimensional system of 12+10×10(12)×12+10‐membered ring (MR) pores. The 10(12) MR pore in the b direction is a 10 MR pore with long 12 MR stretches forming 30 Å long tubular supercages. Along one direction the 10 MR pores are fused, meaning that the separation between adjacent pores consists of a single tetrahedron that is, additionally, connected to only three additional tetrahedra (a Q3). These fused pores are thus decorated by T‐OH groups along the whole diffusion path, creating a hydrophilic region embedded in an otherwise essentially hydrophobic environment. The structure is built from highly porous 12×12×12 MR uninterrupted layers that are connected to each other through Q3 producing a second system of 10×10×10 MR pores. This zeolite can be extensively degermanated yielding a material with high thermal stability, despite its interrupted nature.
item.content:encoded:
HPM-16 is a new interrupted zeolite with 3D intersecting 12+10×10(12)×12+10 MR channels containing 30 Å long supercages. The structure, with a very long b-axis (>50 Å), was solved by state-of-the-art 3D electron diffraction. Degermanated HPM-16 is stable up to 800 °C. Several derived structures were studied, including one recently reported.


Abstract

HPM-16 is a highly porous germanosilicate zeolite with an interrupted framework that contains a three-dimensional system of 12+10×10(12)×12+10-membered ring (MR) pores. The 10(12) MR pore in the b direction is a 10 MR pore with long 12 MR stretches forming 30 Å long tubular supercages. Along one direction the 10 MR pores are fused, meaning that the separation between adjacent pores consists of a single tetrahedron that is, additionally, connected to only three additional tetrahedra (a Q3). These fused pores are thus decorated by T-OH groups along the whole diffusion path, creating a hydrophilic region embedded in an otherwise essentially hydrophobic environment. The structure is built from highly porous 12×12×12 MR uninterrupted layers that are connected to each other through Q3 producing a second system of 10×10×10 MR pores. This zeolite can be extensively degermanated yielding a material with high thermal stability, despite its interrupted nature.
item.dc:creator: Zihao Rei Gao, Salvador R. G. Balestra, Jian Li, Miguel A. Camblor
item.dc:title: HPM‐16, a Stable Interrupted Zeolite with a Multidimensional Mixed Medium–Large Pore System Containing Supercages

item.source: Wiley: Angewandte Chemie International Edition: Table of Contents
item.title: Aptamer–PROTAC Conjugates (APCs) for Tumor‐Specific Targeting in Breast Cancer
item.description: Angewandte Chemie International Edition, EarlyView.
item.dc:description: PROTAC is an emerging new technology in drug discovery. In their Research Article (DOI: 10.1002/anie.202107347), Guoqiang Dong, Chunquan Sheng et al. developed the first aptamer–PROTAC conjugate (APC), which showed improved tumor targeting and in vivo protein degradation, leading to enhanced antitumor potency and decreased toxicity.
